newsitem.title: USA: U.S. airlines raise most domestic fares by 2.5 pct.
newsitem.headline: U.S. airlines raise most domestic fares by 2.5 pct.

text.p: Major airlines except Southwest Airlines Co said Monday they raised their fares by 2.5 percent because of strong passenger demand for seating.
The airlines said the fare increase applied to domestic flights in most routes which do not compete with Southwest and matched a 2.5 percent increase initiated by Continental Airlines Inc.
The fare hikes come on top of the 10 percent federal passenger excise tax reinstated in August, which had prompted some airlines to increase their fares 10 percent.
Airlines that said they raised their fares include Trans World Airlines Inc, UAL Corp, parent of United Airlines, Northwest Airlines Corp and Delta Air Lines Inc and USAir Group Inc.
"We've seen a tremendous demand this summer and our advanced bookings for the fall are looking strong," said Jackie Pate, a Delta spokesperson specializing in pricing.
Pate said Delta's load factor for the calendar year through July was 70.14 percent, compared with 65.13 percent over the same period last year.

"Traditionally after Labor Day travel tends to slacken. That is occuring, but we are still seeing strong demand," said American Airlines spokesman John Hotard. American Air is an AMR Corp subsidiary. Hotard said this year's bookings are up "a couple of percentage points" compared with last year's.
The airlines gave other reasons for the fare increases, including rising fuel costs and the cost of greater security measures.
In August some airlines raised their fares by 10 percent to cover the excise tax, but the fare hike did not stick because it wasn't uniformly matched by all carriers.
Southwest said it absorbed the cost of the tax on most of its routes, except for longer flights, and has so far chosen not to make additional fare increases.

"It was just a business decision. We are the low-fare airline," said Southwest spokesperson Linda Rutherford, adding "We know that the resumption of the (excise) tax will definitely impact profits, but we don't know by how much yet."
